'''{{Pagename nd}}''' is a {{lc:Quest item }} in {{poe2}}. ## Description {{Description |{{#var:description}}}} ## Acquisition {{#arraymap: {{#var:location}}|;|x|x|\n}} ## Usage * As a [Cipher](/cipher/) or [Priest](/priest/), or with the [Clergy](/clergy/) background, or with [Religion](/religion/) 7, you can inspect it to reveal a confusion hex placed within by [Nairi](/nairi/). * With [Xoti](/xoti/) or [Serafen](/serafen/) in the party, they'll chime in too. * You can return the idol to [Nairi](/nairi/), [Vektor](/vektor/), or [Ranga Ruānu](/rangaRuanu/) in [Tikawara](/tikawara/) (see the quest page for more information). ## Trivia * Upon picking it up, the description reads:
The wooden figurine has the body of a woman and the head of a fish, with beady eyes and a gaping, snaggle-toothed maw. It's pale and rough-textured, like it was carved recently.
## Reactivity {| class="wikitable" ! Source ! Reaction |- | [Xoti](/xoti/) | style="font-style:italic" | "Careful, Watcher. That thing's got a nasty hex on it. Confusion, feels like." Xoti's nose crinkles as she leans closer to examine the figurine. |- | [Serafen](/serafen/) | style="font-style:italic" | "Oi, cap. That barnacle bait be radiating confusion, or my blue ass ain't blue. Feel all fathom-headed just looking at it." His ears twitch as he peers narrow-eyed at the figure. |- | As [Cipher](/cipher/) | style="font-style:italic" | But as you study the piece, you get a sudden image of a woman - a priestess - carving it by candlelight, muttering furious, frantic curses. Sure enough, a confusion hex is carved on the bottoms of the feet. |- | With [Clergy](/clergy/) background or as [Priest](/priest/) | style="font-style:italic" | But as your thumb slides across the bottom, you notice something carved there. You probably wouldn't recognize it without your years of religious study, but it looks like a confusion hex. |- | With [Religion](/religion/) 7 | style="font-style:italic" | It looks like an idol of Ngati, the Huana trickster goddess. You know from your studies that idols like this are sometimes used to carry the blessings - or curses - of the gods they represent. Sure enough, scratched under the idol's feet, you see the markings of a confusion hex. |}
